metadata.name: EDDY #60
metadata.description:
An eddy is a circular movement of water counter to a main current. It reminds me of innovations in art, like a small countercurrent to the mainstream, surfacing new techniques and aesthetics. 

I hope that EDDY will brighten your days with its playful swirl of colors, inspired by the sea, the sky, the birds, and post-impressionist paintings.

Keyboard Controls:
[F] Fill the window.
[S] Save the current view in live mode as an image (default 1125x1500px).
[1] [2] [4] [6] Change resolution, 1.5K to 9K.
[R] Reverse course.

Made with p5js and shaders.

Created by elsif, 2022.12.

metadata.name: System Î² #30
metadata.description:
Î± -> Î² is about "Increases in magnitude and decreases in computation". And still related the fleeting time in the generating process.

My role in this work is more of a discoverer than a creator. 

Try to reveal the possibilities of time perception in the generative art through negotiating with incomprehensible mathematical equations.

What I want to explore through this work is that behind the generated results, the dynamic process of generations are equally diverse and unpredictable.

When we watch the generating process displayed on the computer, changing instantly, moving, multiplying, disappearing, and we hesitate, wonder, pause, await, as if many possibilities of time perception have emerged in the fragmented moments.

_
press [1] -> Î² 
press [2] -> Î²â°ã€€ 
press [3] -> Î²Â¹
-
Press [s] in live view to save as PNG.
Press [d] in live view to save as hi-res PNG.
-
If you need your collection in SVG format, feel free to DM me.

metadata.name: n Forms #26
metadata.description:
Hand-scrawled documentation of abstract structures. A journal from another realm.

Press 's' to save an image while in full-screen mode.

If you want to increase the resolution of the saved image, add e.g. &size=2000 after the live/fullscreen view URL to render the canvas at that specific pixel width (default = browser sized). This will be dependent on your system specifications, but outputs of up to 8000px wide, or above, should be possible.

Usually loads best in Chrome

metadata.name: 7.356 degrees #166
metadata.description:
Start with something simple. Take four identical equilateral triangles and join them to form a pyramid. This is your building block â€“ a regular tetrahedron, the simplest possible three-dimensional figure.

When you connect five such pyramids by attaching their faces, you will be left with a thin empty space between the first and last: a volumetric angle of 7.356 degrees. Itâ€™s too small to fit another piece and too big to be lost in numerical imprecision.

It is a surprising imperfection. You would expect a tetrahedron to behave similarly to its two-dimensional ancestor. When you arrange equilateral triangles, one next to the other like tiles, you can cover two-dimensional space without leaving an empty spot. You may go on forever, covering infinite planes and be sure that the six angles that meet at each point will add up to the perfect 360 degrees.

In three dimensions, it is not like this: you cannot use your building block to fully fill a void. Itâ€™s as if the mathematical rules â€“the ones we tend to idealise for elegance, harmony, and infallibilityâ€“ broke when you raise complexity.

But mathematical beauty does not reside in perfection. It is through these exceptions that complexity emerges. So keep building, face by face, one block at a time, and embrace the surprising, chaotic aesthetics that appears. A different type of harmony â€“ not based on impeccable proportions, but on unpredictability.

---

The colours of the structures are inspired by 16 paintings of Polish artists from the 19th and 20th centuries.

"In a window" by Anna BiliÅ„ska-Bohdanowicz
"Portrait of Jadwiga against a Yellow Background" by JÃ³zef Mehoffer
"Portrait of Zofia OkuÅ„" by Edward OkuÅ„
"Girl with chrysanthemums" by Olga BoznaÅ„ska
"Nocturne â€“ Swans in OgrÃ³d Saski in Warsaw by Night" by JÃ³zef Pankiewicz
"Soil" by Ferdynand Ruszczyc
"Obsession" by Wojciech Weiss
"Self-portrait in armour" by Jacek Malczewski
"Self-portrait" by Artur Grottger
"Portrait of Jadwiga Dembowska" by Leopold Horowitz
"Death of Barbara RadziwiÅ‚Å‚" by JÃ³zef Simmler
"Before the Sunrise" by JÃ³zef CheÅ‚moÅ„ski
"With brushwood" by Julian FaÅ‚at
Study for the painting "In a Bower" by Aleksander Gierymski
"Woman Combing her Hair" by WÅ‚adysÅ‚aw ÅšlewiÅ„ski
"Still life with a heron" by WÅ‚adysÅ‚aw CzachÃ³rski

---

Click on the image for resolution options.

In live mode:

Click PNG to save the rendered image. [Saving higher resolutions may not work in some browsers; in these cases, right-click-save the image]

Click STL or PLY to download the digital model to view on your computer or 3d print at home [experimental - highly complex geometries are difficult to 3d print in practice]. The PLY format stores colours of the model that can be visualised in most 3d modelling programs.

---

All drawing and geometric methods are written by mrkswcz using javascript, except for the following:
- three.js (MIT License)
- three-mesh-bvh by Garrett Johnson (MIT License)
- seedrandom by David Bau (MIT License)
- OpenSimplex Noise by Josh Forisha (Public Domain)
- triangle-triangle-intersection by stonkpunk (CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication)
Compiled using fxhash-boilerplate-webpack by fxhash (MIT License). For more information, please see the ./bundle.js.LICENSE.txt file included in the package.

The project uses CPU for calculations and rendering. Generating the image requires up to 500MB of free RAM. Testing was performed across browsers and devices, but please ensure it works on your device before minting.

metadata.name: Kaleidoscopics #17
metadata.description:
Kaleidoscopics is an algorithm that creates animated psychedelic colorscapes.  Just like some classic off-chain psychedelia - kaleidoscopes and tie dies and such - these animated patterns all have a colorful, axial-symmetric, fractally kind of a thing happening.  

Zoom and pan around to find structures at different scales, and if possible, run this on a machine with a graphics card in full screen mode.

Created by @capnganj - one love <3

metadata.name: Mint the Joker #23
metadata.description:
MintTheJoker, MindTheJoker

Play the game of BlackJack in search for the Joker. 

The Joker is rare and will be provided for free for everyone catching #BlackJack (21). Goodluck! #MindTheJoker #MintTheJoker
Â 
In order to provide enough chances to win the #Joker, 18 complete decks are created with 13 ranks in each of four suits: Mossy Green, Navy Teal, Hazy Purple and Oranje Yellow). Each suit includes an Ace, an Extraterrestrial King, a Queen of Dragons and an #Inca Mummy.The simple object of the game is to win a Joker. Number cards count as their number, the Inca Mummy, Queen of Dragons, and Extraterrestrial #King count as 10, and Aces count as either 1 or 11 according to the player's choice. 
Â 
The artwork was based on Colorful Ascending Dragons and Calligraphies based on #SandCastle (https://www.fxhash.xyz/generative/8013)
Â 
Keep or trade these Cards carefully, since more #NFT #Cardgames and therefore more winning opportunities are under development.

metadata.name: RANDOM CHAOS (1/12) #41
metadata.description:
"RANDOM CHAOS" is the first generative artwork build from my first 30 anaglyph 8x8 pixel artworks minted on 8bidou. The 8x8s are exported as .png and randomly layered in a chaotic form using random size and position on the canvas. 

* This token is designed using the 3D Anaglyph Technique. Blue/red Glasses are recommended to fully reveal the artwork 

* Generated from the first 30 pixel artworks minted on-chain on 8bidou

* Saving function: Save your image pressing "s"

* Made with love in p5.js

metadata.name: Sierras #68
metadata.description:
This is meant to look like a hand drawn map you might find in a fantasy book. It's also inspired by the landscapes I've seen along the California coast and the Sierra Nevada mountains.

In live mode, once the art is generated, tap the 's' key to save a large version of it.

Enjoy!

metadata.name: TENDER Pass #818
metadata.description:
Tender is a curatorial platform and community that helps bring incredible works of generative art to discerning collectors.

Holding a TENDER Pass enables enriched benefits and experiences within the Tender ecosystem. Passholders expand their access to unique collaborations with extraordinary artists, indispensable collector tools, curatorial experiences, artwork insights, fine art prints, a thriving community, and more.

Tender is committed to stewarding the growth of generative art and amplifying the voices of artists and collectors across the entire lifecycle: from creation to collection to curation, and back again. Every Pass minted and resold directly enables Tender to continue creating the platform and experiences that serve this mission.

â€”â€”

TENDER Pass features unique artwork by punevyr. While all Passes are special, a small number of randomly generated, rarified tokens will come with boosted benefits. If you have a piece with a dark background of any kind, you likely possess one of the following:

Bonus Pass
TENDER Passes with the special Bonus trait get 1 guaranteed reserve spot on all TENDER x Collab projects

Grail Pass
TENDER Passes with the special Grail trait get 2 free mints on all TENDER x Collab projects


New Passholders may access our Discord server thatâ€™s linked from our website.
For TENDER Pass benefits and up-to-date details, please visit tender.art/pass


Artwork created with p5.js

---

TENDER x punevyr
July 2022

metadata.name: Richter #193
metadata.description:
Richter is the second collaboration of Richard Nadler and Leander Herzog, following their first project called Gerhard. A generative animation based on multiple layers of color and data, mixed, moved and painted over in realtime. Some fragments stick to the canvas while others get discarded to leave the existing layers visible, allowing a complex surface to emerge and build up over time.
 
Richter works with data from 4 of 24 highres images, 30mb in total. This is the maximum size fxhash allows for a project and three times more than Gerhard. Richard Nadler created stunning new textures, enabling more variation in composition and detail to emerge at much higher resolution. Leander Herzog created the code for the interplay between the layers, motion and interactions. Richter elevates the approach from Gerhard with new methods for the realtime rendering process and new features like offline-first caching. Both artists use different tools and are not aware of the details of each others process, meeting through the interface of pixels as data.
 
Richter is featured in the exhibition "Generative Abstraction" at Expanded.art in Berlin.
 
- Click to start a new layer of motion and color.
- Doubleclick to enter fullscreen.
- Press â€œsâ€ to save the canvas.
- Append ?dpr=4 to the url to increase the resolution.

leanderherzog.ch/2023/richter/
leanderherzog.ch/2022/gerhard/
fxhash.xyz/generative/17030/

metadata.name: Mediterranean #120
metadata.description:
How diverse can nature be?

Created with p5js.
Code takes a few minutes to complete. Needs a good CPU.
Works faster on Chrome browser.
For high-res images: Type a resolution multiplier number on live view. If you type 2, it will render 2 times larger than your screen size. Press "s" to save.

metadata.name: Into the Wild #102
metadata.description:
Escape from the wilderness.

Created with p5js.
Contains 10 different color variations.

metadata.name: Miniscapes #294
metadata.description:
Miniscapes merges generative code (Rich's bit) with meticulously designed scenes and elements (Rick's bit), to create minimalist landscapes intended to charm, delight, and surprise.

Our aim was to convey as much as possible with as little as possible by using simple shapes and lines to represent a wide variety of natural landscapes.

We hope that you find as much joy in owning a Miniscape as we did in creating them.

Controls (in live view):
- Press [s] to save the current image
- Press [p] to pause an animated output
- Press [r] to reset an animated output (this will also pause)

metadata.name: overloaded #211
metadata.description: Overloaded attempts to be a system to explore time perception, through non-representative images, while still representing pixels as upscaled forms. It plays with permanence and non-permanence.

metadata.name: RGB Elementary Cellular Automaton #728
metadata.description:
Stephen Wolfram's Elementary Cellular Automaton where 3 different rules are drawn in the Red, Green and Blue color components of the image.

Rules are selected randomly among a pre-selection of 53 rules from which nice behaviors emerge.

Tokens can have a cell size in the [1; 20] range.
